Rationalizing Policy Constraints on National Forest Timber Supply
items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Various policy factors constrain planning for timber from the National Forest System, but their actual effects can only be guessed at. Specific information might alter assumptions the planners now make about trade-offs between timber and other forest goods and services.</jats:p>

title: Environmental Selection and Physician Supply
Water supply for New York City in the 1980s
items.abstract: <jats:p>New York City, perceived as a prototype of aging water systems, faces the four fundamentals of urban water utilities: providing sufficient quantities, maintaining high quality, ensuring reliability of supply, and financing capital needs. The economic viability of New York City—and all older urban areas—depends on meeting these criteria successfully.</jats:p>

title: The arterial blood supply to the tibial tuberosity in the foetus
Optimal Utilization of a Variable Fish Supply
container-title: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
items.abstract: <jats:p> Successful exploitation of a fishery depends not only on the quantity of fish caught and processed, but also on the steadiness of supply. Too much variability in catch means that supplies will sometimes be inadequate, while at other times there will be too many fish to process, and the market will become glutted. Fisheries managers must therefore be prepared to make a trade-off between maximization of mean yield and minimization of the variance of this yield if the fishery is to function optimally. To do this they must understand the economic trade-offs that enter into the catching, processing, and marketing aspects of the fishery. This paper presents a strategy for coupling biological and economic models and illustrates how these questions can be quantified and integrated to arrive at a bioeconomically optimal management strategy.Key words: optimality, variability, fisheries management, sustainable yield </jats:p>

title: The production of public supply drinking water from Rutland Water at the wing treatment works
Social Costs of Supply‐Restricting Marketing Boards
container-title: Canadian Journal of Agricultural Economics/Revue canadienne d'agroeconomie
items.abstract: <jats:p>This article uses the concepts of economic surplus to assess the transfer and social cost effects of the national supply management programs for poultry products. The focus is on analytical and methodological issues and problems of identifying and quantifying these effects. It is apparent that different estimating methods and assumptions lead to considerable differences in the social cost estimates. Nonetheless, short‐run losses in allocative efficiency are relatively minor compared to the transfer effects. However, the potential long‐run losses in efficiency are substantial.</jats:p><jats:p>Cet article utilise les concepts de surplus économiques pour évaluer les effets de transfert et de coúts sociaux dans les programmes hationaux de gestion de I'approvisionnement en volailles. Nous porterons notre attention sur les questions analytiques et méthodologiques et sur les problémes d'identification et de quantification de ces effets. II est évident que des méthoaes devaluation et des hypothéses différentes entraínent des differences considé fOlOrables dans Vestimation des coÜts sociaux. Pourtant, lespertes à court terme dues à une mauvaise distribution sont relativement minimes par rapport aux effets de transfert. Mais les pertes à long terme, pertes potentielles en efficacité sont substantielles.</jats:p>

Geosmin and 2-Methylisoborneol from Cyanobacteria in Three Water Supply Systems
items.abstract:
<jats:p>
            Three
            <jats:italic>Oscillatoria</jats:italic>
            strains and one
            <jats:italic>Anabaena</jats:italic>
            species were isolated from three different water supply systems in California that experienced earthy-musty taste and odor problems in their drinking water. Unialgal cultures, free of actinomycetes, were purged using the Grob closed-loop stripping analysis method, and the resulting methylene chloride extracts were analyzed on a gas chromatograph/mass spectrometer. Geosmin was produced by
            <jats:italic>Oscillatoria simplicissima</jats:italic>
            and
            <jats:italic>Anabaena scheremetievi</jats:italic>
            , and 2-methylisoborneol was produced by
            <jats:italic>O. curviceps</jats:italic>
            and
            <jats:italic>O. tenuis.</jats:italic>
            These compounds are the two major causes of earthy-musty tastes and odors in water. In three instances, the major odorant found in culture was previously identified in the water or sediment sample from which the respective organism was isolated.
            <jats:italic>O. curviceps</jats:italic>
            was implicated in a taste and odor episode involving 2-methylisoborneol in a major reservoir. Geosmin and 2-methylisoborneol were easily detected with culture samples of only 4 to 25 ml.
          </jats:p>

Simultaneous measurement of coronary venous blood flow and oxygen saturation during transient alterations in myocardial oxygen supply and demand
Assessment of Lead Intakes and Dose-response for a Population in Ayr Exposed to a Plumbosolvent Water Supply
items.abstract: <jats:p> 1 Dietary lead intakes, blood lead concentrations and water lead concentrations were measured and their relationships investigated for 31 adults and 11 infants living in dwellings in Ayr with lead plumbing. </jats:p><jats:p> 2 For adults, some lead intakes were found to be higher than the provisional tolerable weekly intake for lead, and for infants most of the intakes were high. </jats:p><jats:p> 3 A cube root relationship fitted the data on blood lead versus water lead better than a linear relationship. Similarly, blood lead varied with the cube root of weekly dietary lead intake. </jats:p><jats:p> 4 These cube root equations provided a means of estimating the impact on blood lead concentrations of exposure to lead from food and water. If cube root relationships correctly describe the association between these parameters, then the curve fitted to the results for adults indicates that the contribution to the blood lead concentrations from sources other than the diet and water was relatively small. </jats:p>

title: Effect of nitrogen‐mediated changes in alkalinity on pH control and CO<sub>2</sub> supply in intensive microalgal cultures
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The freshwater alga <jats:italic>Scenedesmus obliquus</jats:italic> was grown in continuous culture at a fixed dilution rate of 0.5/day, but at varying pH in the range 4.17–10.67. The pH was regulated in the range 4.17–7.67 by continuously bubbling 1% CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>‐enriched air into the cultures and by varying the source of nitrogen (NO<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-1.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00063592:media:BIT260240308:tex2gif-stack-1" />, NH<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-2.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00063592:media:BIT260240308:tex2gif-stack-2" />, or urea) in the growth medium, which, in turn, led to changes in culture alkalinity. Culture alkalinity and <jats:italic>P</jats:italic><jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-inf-6.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00063592:media:BIT260240308:tex2gif-inf-6" /> were the sole determinants of pH. A pH‐stat system, together with NO<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-3.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00063592:media:BIT260240308:tex2gif-stack-3" /> in the medium, was used to regulate the pH in the range 7.92–10.67. Maximum productivity, which occurred at pH 6.6, was dependent on N source only to the extent that culture alkalinity was a function of nitrogen uptake. The results demonstrate that the choice of N is a critical factor in controlling the pH of large‐scale algal cultures. NH<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-4.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00063592:media:BIT260240308:tex2gif-stack-4" /> is a poor source of N because it leads to destruction of culture alkalinity and concomitant growth‐inhibiting reductions in pH, whereas NO<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-5.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00063592:media:BIT260240308:tex2gif-stack-5" /> has an opposite effect, although pH is not so severely affected in this case. Urea is, by far, the most suitable N source for maximizing algal yield when it is supplied in combination with the proper amounts of HCO<jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/tex2gif-stack-6.gif" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:00063592:media:BIT260240308:tex2gif-stack-6" /> alkalinity in the growth medium and percent CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in the bubbled gas that will lead to an equilibrium pH near the optimum pH.</jats:p>

title: Synthetic fuels needed despite current oil glut
Modern Europe - Public Policy and the Supply of Coal to London, 1700–1770. By William J. Hausman. New York: Arno Press, Dissertations in European Economic History, 1981. Pp. x, 306. $28.00 cloth.
Phosphorus Accumulation and Toxicity in Leaves in Relation to Zinc Supply
container-title: Soil Science Society of America Journal
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The relationship of zinc (Zn) deficiency to phosphorus (P) toxicity was examined in ‘Emerald’ okra [<jats:italic>Abelmoschus esculentus</jats:italic> (L.) Moench] grown for 21 days (D<jats:sub>21</jats:sub>) in complete nutrient solution and then transferred to treatments with two levels of P (P<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, P<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> = 250, 2,000 µ<jats:italic>M</jats:italic> P) and four levels of Zn (Zn<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, Zn<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, Zn<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>, Zn<jats:sub>4</jats:sub> = 0, 0.25, 1, 2 µ<jats:italic>M</jats:italic> added Zn).</jats:p><jats:p>No symptoms of “little leaf” or “rosetting” developed in any plants. “Mottle leaf” symptoms developed as chlorotic and necrotic patches in the interveinal areas of the older leaves of Zn<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> plants at P<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> and in Zn<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, Zn<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and Zn<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> plants at P<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>. Thus, increasing the level of P induced symptoms which were eliminated by adding Zn.</jats:p><jats:p>Treatments had little effect on dry matter at D<jats:sub>45</jats:sub> and D<jats:sub>63</jats:sub>: at D<jats:sub>111</jats:sub>, low Zn depressed dry weight of P<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> tops and even more markedly depressed dry weight of P<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> tops, roots, and fruits.</jats:p><jats:p>Increasing solution P increased the concentration and amount of P in all plant parts at all harvests. At D<jats:sub>45</jats:sub> it also depressed Zn concentrations in all parts of Zn<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> plants but in no other Zn treatment and in no treatment at later harvests.</jats:p><jats:p>At Zn<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, leaves had relatively low concentrations of Zn and high concentrations of P. Increasing levels of Zn enhanced their Zn concentrations and depressed their P concentrations; at D<jats:sub>45</jats:sub> and D<jats:sub>63</jats:sub> they also depressed the concentrations and total amounts of P in tops and whole plants but increased them in roots. Thus Zn deficiency markedly enhanced P absorption by roots, transport to tops, and accumulation in leaves.</jats:p><jats:p>Concentrations of magnesium in plant organs responded to treatments in the same way as did P but to a smaller degree, particularly in the leaves. No other element measured (Ca, K, Na, Fe, Cu, Mn) responded in the same way.</jats:p><jats:p>The development and intensity of symptoms in old leaves correlated closely with P concentrations. Leaves with faint symptoms had 0.8% P; those with marked symptoms had > 1.5% P; and dead leaves had nearly 5% P. The intensification of symptoms is attributed to accumulation of P to toxic levels in leaves.</jats:p><jats:p>It is suggested that Zn deficiency interferes with P metabolism enhancing the amounts of P absorbed by roots and transported to tops: under conditions of high P supply, P accumulates to toxic levels in leaves inducing or accentuating symptoms resembling Zn deficiency. This effect of Zn on P metabolism in roots seems to explain previously puzzling observations in which P treatments enhanced symptoms of Zn deficiency without any reduction in Zn contents of plant tops: there is no need to invoke any effect of P in inactivating Zn in leaves.</jats:p>
